Setup

Recall the L2L^2L2 regularized least squares problem (i.e., ridge regression),

\begin{align} u_{\star} &:= \text{argmin}_{u \in \mathbb{R}^d} J(u) \tag{1} \newline J(u) &:= \frac{1}{2} \lVert y - Gu\rVert^2_{\Sigma} + \frac{1}{2}\lVert u-m \rVert^2_{C} \end{align}

where y∈Rny \in \R^ny∈Rn and m∈Rdm \in \R^dm∈Rd are fixed vectors, G∈Rn×dG \in \R^{n \times d}G∈Rn×d is the linear forward model, and Σ∈Rn×n\Sigma \in \R^{n \times n}Σ∈Rn×n and C∈Rd×dC \in \R^{d \times d}C∈Rd×d are positive definite matrices. In (1) we have used the following notation for inner products and norms weighted by a positive definite matrix CCC: \begin{align} \langle v, v^\prime \rangle_C &:= \langle C^{-1}v, v^\prime\rangle = v^\top C^{-1}v^\prime \newline \lVert v \rVert_C^2 &:= \langle v, v\rangle_C. \end{align}

A solution to (1) can be viewed as a maximum a posteriori (MAP) estimate under the Bayesian model \begin{align} y|u &\sim \mathcal{N}(Gu, \Sigma) \tag{3} \newline u &\sim \mathcal{N}(m, C). \tag{4} \end{align}

I discuss this problem in depth in my post, on the linear Gaussian model, where I show that the solution can be written as the following equivalent expressions, \begin{align} u_{\star} &= \left(G^\top \Sigma^{-1}G + C^{-1}\right)^{-1}\left(G^\top \Sigma^{-1}y + C^{-1}m \right) \tag{5} \newline u_{\star} &= m + CG^\top \left(GCG^\top + \Sigma \right)^{-1}(y-Gm). \tag{6} \end{align}

In this post we will consider a generalization of problem (1), where CCC is only required to be positive semidefinite (not strictly positive definite). In particular, this means that the inverse C−1C^{-1}C−1 may not exist. It is interesting to note that, although (5) depends on C−1C^{-1}C−1, the inverse does not appear anywhere in the equivalent expression (6). This leads to the natural question of whether (6) still provides a valid solution to the optimization problem even when CCC is singular. The first step in investigating this question will be providing a suitable generalization of the objective function in (1), since the expression ∥u−m∥C2=∥C−1/2(u−m)∥2\lVert u - m\rVert^2_{C} = \lVert C^{-1/2}(u - m)\rVert^2∥u−m∥C2​=∥C−1/2(u−m)∥2 is not well-defined when CCC is singular.

Generalizing the Optimization Problem

Our goal is now to extend (1) to the case where CCC need not be strictly positive definite. We start by generalizing (1) through the definition of a constrained optimization problem on an extended parameter space. We then provide two approaches to formulate this problem in an unconstrained fashion, each of which leads to equivalent closed-from solutions. We will find it convenient to define notation for the “centered” quantities \begin{align} &u^\prime := u - m, &&y^\prime := y - Gm \tag{7} \end{align} so that y−Gu=(y−Gm)−G(u−m)=y′−Gu′.(8) y - Gu = (y - Gm) - G(u-m) = y^\prime - Gu^\prime. \tag{8} y−Gu=(y−Gm)−G(u−m)=y′−Gu′.(8)

Constrained Formulation

We start by considering the constrained formulation. This section follows the approach in section 8.1.2 of (Sanz-Alonso et al., 2023). To start, note that when CCC is positive definite, we have ∥u−m∥C2=∥u′∥C2=⟨C−1u′,u′⟩=⟨b,u′⟩,(9) \lVert u - m\rVert^2_C = \lVert u^\prime \rVert^2_C = \langle C^{-1}u^\prime, u^\prime\rangle = \langle b, u^\prime \rangle, \tag{9} ∥u−m∥C2​=∥u′∥C2​=⟨C−1u′,u′⟩=⟨b,u′⟩,(9) where b∈Rdb \in \mathbb{R}^db∈Rd solves Cb=u′.(10) Cb = u^\prime. \tag{10} Cb=u′.(10) When CCC is invertible, the unique bbb solving (10) is simply found by multiplying both sides by C−1C^{-1}C−1. When CCC is not invertible, then there may be zero or infinitely many such solutions. As long as there is at least one solution to (10) we can give meaning to expression (9) by picking a particular bbb that solves (10). Now that we have introduced a new variable bbb, we might consider generalizing (1) by jointly optimizing over (u,b)(u,b)(u,b) subject to the linear constraint Cb=u′Cb = u^\primeCb=u′.

Constrained Joint Optimization.
\begin{align} (u_{\star}, b_{\star}) &\in \text{argmin}_{(u,b) \in \mathcal{S}} J(u,b) \tag{11} \newline J(u,b) &:= \frac{1}{2} \lVert y - Gu\rVert^2_{\Sigma} + \frac{1}{2}\langle b, u-m \rangle \newline \mathcal{S} &:= \left\{(u,b) : Cb = u-m \right\}. \end{align}

Note that if CCC is positive definite, then (11) reduces to (1). If the problem is solved for (u⋆,b⋆)(u_{\star}, b_{\star})(u⋆​,b⋆​), then the desired solution can be obtained by extracting u⋆u_{\star}u⋆​ and discarding the nuisance parameter b⋆b_{\star}b⋆​.

Lagrange Multipliers

Observe that (11) can be viewed as optimizing J(u,b)J(u,b)J(u,b) subject to the constraint g(u,b)=0g(u,b) = 0g(u,b)=0, where g(u,b)=Cb−(u−m)g(u,b) = Cb - (u-m)g(u,b)=Cb−(u−m). This is a typical setup for Lagrange multipliers. We therefore introduce the Lagrange multiplier λ∈Rd\lambda \in \mathbb{R}^dλ∈Rd, which allows us to cast the constrained optimization over (u,b)(u,b)(u,b) as an unconstrained optimization over (u,b,λ)(u,b,\lambda)(u,b,λ).

Lagrange Multiplier Formulation.
\begin{align} (u_{\star}, b_{\star}, \lambda_{\star}) &\in \text{argmin}_{u,b,\lambda} J(u,b,\lambda) \tag{12} \newline J(u,b,\lambda) &:= \frac{1}{2} \lVert y - Gu\rVert^2_{\Sigma} + \frac{1}{2}\langle b, u-m \rangle + \langle \lambda, Cb - u + m \rangle. \end{align}

We have succeeding in converting the problem to one that can be solved by analytical means; namely, by solving the system of equations ∇uJ=∇bJ=∇λJ=0.(13) \nabla_{u} J = \nabla_{b} J = \nabla_{\lambda} J = 0. \tag{13} ∇u​J=∇b​J=∇λ​J=0.(13)

This derivation is provided in the appendix, and the result is summarized below.

Solution of Lagrange Multiplier Formulation.
A solution (u⋆,b⋆,λ⋆)(u_{\star}, b_{\star}, \lambda_{\star})(u⋆​,b⋆​,λ⋆​) of (12), projected onto the uuu-component, is given by u⋆=m+Cb⋆,(14) u_{\star} = m + Cb_{\star}, \tag{14} u⋆​=m+Cb⋆​,(14) where b⋆=[(G⊤Σ−1G)C+I]−1G⊤Σ−1(y−Gm).(15) b_{\star} = \left[(G^\top \Sigma^{-1}G)C + I \right]^{-1}G^\top \Sigma^{-1}(y-Gm). \tag{15} b⋆​=[(G⊤Σ−1G)C+I]−1G⊤Σ−1(y−Gm).(15) It also holds that C[(G⊤Σ−1G)C+I]−1G⊤Σ−1=CG⊤(GCG⊤+Σ)−1,(16) C\left[(G^\top \Sigma^{-1}G)C + I \right]^{-1}G^\top \Sigma^{-1} = CG^\top \left(GCG^\top + \Sigma \right)^{-1}, \tag{16} C[(G⊤Σ−1G)C+I]−1G⊤Σ−1=CG⊤(GCG⊤+Σ)−1,(16) which implies that (14) agrees with expression (6).

Basis Approach

We now consider an alternative approach that avoids the joint optimization over (u,b)(u,b)(u,b). Similar exposition can be found in section 8.3 of (Evensen et al., 2022). Looking back to (9), instead of choosing to optimize over all bbb satisfying (10), we will instead simply choose a particular bbb satisfying this constraint. This only makes sense if the particular choice of bbb does not matter; i.e., if the value of ⟨b,u′⟩\langle b, u^\prime \rangle⟨b,u′⟩ is the same for any bbb solving (10). The below propostion shows that this is indeed the case.

Proposition.
Let u∈Rdu \in \mathbb{R}^du∈Rd be a vector such that there is at least one solution b∈Rdb \in \mathbb{R}^db∈Rd to Cb=u′Cb = u^\primeCb=u′. Then ⟨b,u′⟩\langle b, u^\prime \rangle⟨b,u′⟩ and J(u,b)J(u,b)J(u,b) are constant for any choice of bbb solving this linear system.

Proof. Let b,b′∈Rdb, b^\prime \in \R^db,b′∈Rd satisfy Cb=Cb′=u′Cb = Cb^\prime = u^\primeCb=Cb′=u′. It thus follows that ⟨b,u′⟩−⟨b′,u′⟩=⟨b−b′,u′⟩=⟨b−b′,Cb⟩=⟨C(b−b′),b⟩=⟨0,b⟩=0, \langle b, u^\prime\rangle - \langle b^\prime, u^\prime\rangle = \langle b - b^\prime, u^\prime\rangle = \langle b - b^\prime, Cb\rangle = \langle C(b - b^\prime), b\rangle = \langle 0, b\rangle = 0, ⟨b,u′⟩−⟨b′,u′⟩=⟨b−b′,u′⟩=⟨b−b′,Cb⟩=⟨C(b−b′),b⟩=⟨0,b⟩=0, where we have used the linearity of the inner product and the fact that CCC is symmetric. Since the inner product term in (11) is the only portion with dependence on bbb, it follows that J(v,b)=J(v,b′)J(v,b) = J(v,b^\prime)J(v,b)=J(v,b′). ■\qquad \blacksquare■

Thus, for each uuu that yields a consistent system Cb=u′Cb = u^\primeCb=u′, we can simply pick any solution bbb to insert into ⟨b,u′⟩\langle b, u^\prime\rangle⟨b,u′⟩. The objective will be well-defined since the above result verifies that the specific choice of bbb is inconsequential. A natural choice is to select the bbb of minimal norm; that is, b†:=argminCb=u′∥b∥.(17) b^{\dagger} := \text{argmin}_{Cb=u^\prime} \lVert b \rVert. \tag{17} b†:=argminCb=u′​∥b∥.(17) This unique minimal norm solution is guaranteed to exist and is conveniently given by the Moore-Penrose pseudoinverse b†=C†u′.(18) b^{\dagger} = C^{\dagger}u^\prime. \tag{18} b†=C†u′.(18) Note that when CCC is positive definite, C†=C−1C^{\dagger} = C^{-1}C†=C−1. We can now eliminate the requirement to optimize over bbb by considering the following optimization problem.

Pseudoinverse Formulation.
\begin{align} u_{\star} &\in \text{argmin}_{u \in \mathcal{S}} J(u) \tag{19} \newline J(u) &:= \frac{1}{2} \lVert y - Gu\rVert^2_{\Sigma} + \frac{1}{2}\langle C^{\dagger}(u-m), u-m \rangle \newline \mathcal{S} &:= \left\{u \in \mathbb{R}^d: u-m \in \mathcal{R}(C) \right\} \end{align}

Note that we are now required to reintroduce a constraint set S\mathcal{S}S. This is due to the fact that the pseudoinverse produces a solution bbb to Cb=u′Cb = u^\primeCb=u′ when a solution exists, but we must still explicitly restrict the search space to uuu that admit a consistent system Cb=u′Cb = u^\primeCb=u′; i.e., u′∈R(C)u^\prime \in \mathcal{R}(C)u′∈R(C). The previous approach dealt with this issue by introducing a Lagrange multiplier λ\lambdaλ. We now show that (18) can be written as an unconstrained problem without extending the parameter space. This relies on the following important fact.

Subspace Property.
Let A∈Rd×rA \in \mathbb{R}^{d \times r}A∈Rd×r be a matrix of rank r≤dr \leq dr≤d satisfying C=AA⊤C = AA^\topC=AA⊤. Then a solution to the optimization problem (19) is constrained to the rrr-dimensional affine subspace m+R(C)=m+R(A).(20) m + \mathcal{R}(C) = m + \mathcal{R}(A). \tag{20} m+R(C)=m+R(A).(20)

This is simply a rewriting of the requirement u′=u−m∈R(C)u^\prime = u-m \in \mathcal{R}(C)u′=u−m∈R(C). The solution is constrained by the rank of the subspace R(C)\mathcal{R}(C)R(C). If r=dr = dr=d (i.e., CCC is full-rank) then we recover the typical unconstrained least squares problem. In general, r<dr < dr<d so the columns of CCC are linearly dependent. We therefore introduce the matrix AAA whose columns a1,…,ara_1, \dots, a_ra1​,…,ar​ form a basis for the range of CCC; i.e., the columns of CCC and AAA have the same span.

To implicitly encode the constraint u′∈R(C)u^\prime \in \mathcal{R}(C)u′∈R(C), we can look for solutions in m+R(A)m + \mathcal{R}(A)m+R(A). Any vector in this space can be written as u=m+∑j=1rwjaj=m+Aw,(21) u = m + \sum_{j=1}^{r} w_j a_j = m + Aw, \tag{21} u=m+j=1∑r​wj​aj​=m+Aw,(21) for some weight vector w:=(w1,…,wr)⊤∈Rrw := (w_1, \dots, w_r)^\top \in \mathbb{R}^rw:=(w1​,…,wr​)⊤∈Rr. We can now substitute m+Awm + Awm+Aw for uuu and AA⊤AA^\topAA⊤ for CCC in (19) and thus formulate the optimization over the weights www: J(w):=12∥y−G(m+Aw)∥Σ2+12⟨(AA⊤)†Aw,Aw⟩.(22) J(w) := \frac{1}{2}\lVert y - G(m+Aw)\rVert^2_{\Sigma} + \frac{1}{2}\langle (AA^\top)^{\dagger}Aw, Aw \rangle. \tag{22} J(w):=21​∥y−G(m+Aw)∥Σ2​+21​⟨(AA⊤)†Aw,Aw⟩.(22) The optimization is now over w∈Rrw \in \R^rw∈Rr so we have succeeded in writing (18) as an unconstrained problem. We can simplify this even further using the following properties of the pseudoinverse:

  1. By definition, the pseudoinverse satisfies A=A(A†A)A = A(A^{\dagger}A)A=A(A†A).
  2. The matrix A†AA^{\dagger}AA†A is a projection onto the rowspace of AAA; in particular it is idempotent (i.e., (A†A)2=A†A(A^{\dagger}A)^2 = A^{\dagger}A(A†A)2=A†A) and symmetric.
  3. The following identity holds: A†=A⊤(AA⊤)†A^{\dagger} = A^\top (AA^\top)^{\dagger}A†=A⊤(AA⊤)†.

We can thus simplify the second term in (22) as \begin{align} \langle (AA^\top)^{\dagger}Aw, Aw\rangle = \langle A^\top(AA^\top)^{\dagger}Aw, w\rangle = \langle (A^{\dagger}A)w, w\rangle &= \langle (A^{\dagger}A)^2w, w\rangle \newline &= \langle (A^{\dagger}A)w, (A^{\dagger}A)w\rangle \newline &= \lVert (A^{\dagger}A)w \rVert^2, \tag{23} \end{align} where the second equality uses the third pseudinverse property above. The third and fourth equalities follow from the fact that A†AA^{\dagger}AA†A is idempotent and symmetric. We can thus re-parameterize as w~:=(A†A)w,(24) \tilde{w} := (A^{\dagger}A)w, \tag{24} w~:=(A†A)w,(24) and note that by the first pseudoinverse property we have Aw=A(A†A)w=Aw~,(25) Aw = A(A^{\dagger}A)w = A\tilde{w}, \tag{25} Aw=A(A†A)w=Aw~,(25) which allows us to replace AwAwAw by Aw~A\tilde{w}Aw~ in the first term in (22). We obtain J(w~):=12∥y−G(m+Aw~)∥Σ2+12∥w~∥2.(26) J(\tilde{w}) := \frac{1}{2} \lVert y - G(m + A\tilde{w})\rVert_{\Sigma}^2 + \frac{1}{2} \lVert \tilde{w} \rVert^2 . \tag{26} J(w~):=21​∥y−G(m+Aw~)∥Σ2​+21​∥w~∥2.(26) We see that (26) is the sum of a model-data fit term plus a simple L2L^2L2 penalty on the weights. This final formulation is summarized below, where we have re-labelled w~\tilde{w}w~ as www to lighten notation.

Unconstrained Pseudoinverse Formulation.
The optimization problem in (19) can equivalently be formulated as the unconstrained problem \begin{align} w_{\star} &\in \text{argmin}_{w \in \mathbb{R}^r} J(w) \tag{27} \newline J(w) &:= \frac{1}{2} \lVert y^\prime - GAw\rVert_{\Sigma}^2 + \frac{1}{2}\lVert w \rVert^2 \end{align}

One might initially take issue with the claim that (27) is actually unconstrained given that it relies on the re-parameterization (24), which constrains the weights to lie in the range of A†AA^{\dagger}AA†A. However, recalling that A†AA^{\dagger}AA†A is an orthogonal projection, we have the following projection property: ∥w~∥2=∥(A†A)w∥2≤∥w∥2.(28) \lVert \tilde{w} \rVert^2 = \lVert (A^{\dagger}A)w \rVert^2 \leq \lVert w \rVert^2. \tag{28} ∥w~∥2=∥(A†A)w∥2≤∥w∥2.(28) In other words, allowing the weights to be unconstrained can only increase the objective function (since switching www and w~\tilde{w}w~ has no effect on the first term in (26)), so we are justified in considering the weights to be unconstrained in (27). In fact, we could have jumped right to this conclusion from (23) and avoided needing to define w~\tilde{w}w~ at all.

The following result provides the solution to (27), which immediately follows from the observation that (27) is a standard least squares problem.

Solution of Unconstrained Pseudoinverse formulation.
The minimizing weight of the optimization problem in (26) is given by w⋆=A⊤G⊤(GCG⊤+Σ)−1y′,(29) w_{\star} = A^\top G^\top \left(GCG^\top + \Sigma \right)^{-1}y^\prime, \tag{29} w⋆​=A⊤G⊤(GCG⊤+Σ)−1y′,(29) which implies the optimal parameter \begin{align} u_{\star} &= m + Aw_{\star} \newline &= m + CG^\top \left(GCG^\top + \Sigma \right)^{-1}(y - Gm) \end{align} agrees with the typical least squares solution in (6).

Proof. Observe that (27) is of the form (1) with u:=wu := wu:=w, y′:=yy^\prime := yy′:=y, G:=GAG := GAG:=GA, and C:=IC := IC:=I. Thus, we apply (6) to obtain \begin{align} w_{\star} &:= (GA)^\top \left[(GA)(GA)^\top + \Sigma \right]^{-1}y^\prime \newline &= A^\top G^\top \left[GCG^\top + \Sigma \right]^{-1}(y-Gm), \end{align} where the second equality uses C=AA⊤C = AA^\topC=AA⊤. We thus have \begin{align} u_{\star} &= m + Aw_{\star} \newline &= m + (AA^\top) G^\top \left[GCG^\top + \Sigma \right]^{-1}(y-Gm) \newline &= C G^\top \left[GCG^\top + \Sigma \right]^{-1}(y-Gm), \end{align} which exactly agrees with (6). \qquad \blacksquare

Concluding Notes

We have successfully shown that the optimum (6) continues to hold for the generalization (11) of the least squares formulation, even when CCC is singular. We provided two different derivations of the solution, resulting in the expressions (14) and (29), both of which agree with u⋆u_{\star}u⋆​ as given in (6). We conclude with a few brief follow-up comments.

Uniqueness

Our derivations show that the optimum u⋆u_{\star}u⋆​ is unique, even when CCC is singular. Note that this does not imply that a solution (u⋆,b⋆)(u_{\star}, b_{\star})(u⋆​,b⋆​) to (11) is unique, since many choices of bbb may lead to the same value of the objective. Indeed, u⋆=m+Cb⋆u_{\star} = m + Cb_{\star}u⋆​=m+Cb⋆​ but it may be that u⋆=m+Cb′u_{\star} = m + Cb^\primeu⋆​=m+Cb′ for some other b′∈Sb^\prime \in \mathcal{S}b′∈S. n particular, if u⋆u_{\star}u⋆​ is optimal, then (u⋆,b′)(u_{\star}, b^\prime)(u⋆​,b′) minimizes J(u,b)J(u,b)J(u,b) for any b′b^\primeb′ satisfying Cb′=u⋆−mCb^\prime = u_{\star} - mCb′=u⋆​−m. This follows immediately from the result that the particular bbb solving this linear system does not change the value of the objective. Given that the particular choice of bbb is inconsequential, then a particular rule for choosing bbb will not affect the optimal u⋆u_{\star}u⋆​. The specific approach of choosing the minimal norm bbb led to the least squares problem (27), which we know has a unique solution. Therefore, if (11) has a solution, then it is unique. We summarize this below.

Uniqueness.
If the solution set S\mathcal{S}S is non-empty, then there is a unique optimal value u⋆u_{\star}u⋆​ solving (11).

Representations of the solution

Continuing the above discussion, it should also be emphasized that, while the solution is unique, there may be many different ways to represent it. To see this, consider that (14) gives the solution in the form u⋆=m+Cb⋆u_{\star} = m + Cb_{\star}u⋆​=m+Cb⋆​, for a weight vector b⋆b_{\star}b⋆​. But in general CCC has linearly dependent columns, and thus there may be multiple sets of weights that give rise to the same vector. In (29) the solution is instead represented in the form u⋆=m+Aw⋆u_{\star} = m + Aw_{\star}u⋆​=m+Aw⋆​. If we assume that the columns of AAA are linearly independent, thus providing a basis for R(C)\mathcal{R}(C)R(C), then this provides the unique representation of the solution with respect to the particular basis a1,…,ara_1, \dots, a_ra1​,…,ar​. Note that the two representations are connected by u⋆=m+Cb⋆=m+AA⊤b⋆=m+A(A⊤b⋆).(29) u_{\star} = m + Cb_{\star} = m + AA^\top b_{\star} = m + A(A^\top b_{\star}) \tag{29}. u⋆​=m+Cb⋆​=m+AA⊤b⋆​=m+A(A⊤b⋆​).(29) If the columns of AAA are independent, then (29) implies w⋆=A⊤b⋆w_{\star} = A^\top b_{\star}w⋆​=A⊤b⋆​.

Applications

Why should we even care about the case when CCC is singular? The main application that motivated this post comes from the field of data assimilation. In this context, the parameter and data dimensions ddd and nnn can be massive, potentially precluding storing the matrices Σ\SigmaΣ or CCC. A common solution to this problem is to replace the true CCC with a low-rank approximation of the form C=1r−1∑j=1r(u(j)−m)(u(j)−m)⊤,(30) C = \frac{1}{r-1} \sum_{j=1}^{r} (u^{(j)} - m)(u^{(j)} - m)^\top, \tag{30} C=r−11​j=1∑r​(u(j)−m)(u(j)−m)⊤,(30) where r<dr < dr<d. This Monte Carlo approximation results in a sample covariance matrix CCC that has rank at most rrr. Here, {u(j)}\{u^{(j)}\}{u(j)} is a set of rrr samples used to compute the sample covariance. If we define AAA to be the d×rd \times rd×r matrix with jthj^{\text{th}}jth row equal to 1r−1(u(j)−m)\frac{1}{\sqrt{r-1}}\left(u^{(j)} - m\right)r−1​1​(u(j)−m), then we see that C=AA⊤C = AA^\topC=AA⊤. The matrix AAA is full rank if the vectors {u(j)}\{u^{(j)}\}{u(j)} are independent.

Appendix

Proof: Solution for Lagrange Multiplier Formulation

We derive expressions (14), (15) and (16), the latter showing that the solution agrees with (6).

Deriving (14) and (15)

We start by computing the gradients with respect to uuu, bbb, and λ\lambdaλ: \begin{align} \nabla_{u}J &= -G^\top \Sigma^{-1}(y-Gu) + \frac{1}{2}b - \lambda \tag{31} \newline \nabla_{b}J &= \frac{1}{2}u^\prime + C\lambda \newline \nabla_{\lambda}J &= Cb - u^\prime. \end{align} where we recall the definition u′:=u−mu^\prime := u - mu′:=u−m. We now solve the system of equations ∇uJ=∇bJ=∇λJ=0\nabla_{u}J = \nabla_{b}J = \nabla_{\lambda}J = 0∇u​J=∇b​J=∇λ​J=0 for the three unknowns. Focusing on the last two equations, if we compute 2∇bJ+∇λJ=02\nabla_{b}J + \nabla_{\lambda}J = 02∇b​J+∇λ​J=0 we obtain the optimality criterion C(b+2λ)=0,(32) C(b + 2\lambda) = 0, \tag{32} C(b+2λ)=0,(32) or equivalently, b+2λ∈N(C),(33) b + 2\lambda \in \mathcal{N}(C), \tag{33} b+2λ∈N(C),(33) where N(C)\mathcal{N}(C)N(C) denotes the null space of CCC. The null space of CCC may be nontrivial, which aligns with the above discussion that many values of bbb may yield the optimal solution. We consider taking the minimal norm solution b⋆+2λ⋆=0,(34) b_{\star} + 2\lambda_{\star} = 0, \tag{34} b⋆​+2λ⋆​=0,(34) which implies λ⋆=−12b⋆\lambda_{\star} = -\frac{1}{2}b_{\star}λ⋆​=−21​b⋆​. entry.title: Markov Melding
entry.content:
In this post, I summarize a technique called Markov melding, originally proposed in Goudie et al (2023).

Motivation and Setup

Models of complex systems (climate, disease, etc.) are typically composed of many sub-models. For example, climate models couple together models of the atmosphere, land, ocean, and cryosphere. The component models may be developed largely in isolation, before being combined with the others to form a complex model for the whole system. In the context of Markov melding, we are considering that these component models are specified within a Bayesian framework, so that each component can be identified with a joint probability distribution of the component model parameters and data. Letting MMM denote the number of components, we denote the density for the joint distribution of the mthm^{\text{th}}mth submodel by \begin{align} &p_m(\phi, \psi_m, Y_m), &&m = 1, \dots, M \tag{1} \end{align} where YmY_mYm​ denotes the data used in the mthm^{\text{th}}mth submodel. The submodel parameters are θm:=(ϕ,ψm),(2) \theta_m := (\phi, \psi_m), \tag{2} θm​:=(ϕ,ψm​),(2) and we make a distinction between component-specific parameters ψm\psi_mψm​ and parameters ϕ\phiϕ that are shared across all submodels. Goudie et al (2019) refer to ϕ\phiϕ as the link parameters. A typical modeling workflow might involve obtaining the posterior distributions pm(ϕ,ψm∣Ym)p_m(\phi, \psi_m|Y_m)pm​(ϕ,ψm​∣Ym​) for each submodel independently, and then combining them post-hoc in some fashion to study the system as a whole. Bayesian melding is an alternative approach that seeks to construct a joint distribution p(ϕ,ψ1,…,ψm,Y1,…,Ym)p(\phi, \psi_1, \dots, \psi_m, Y_1, \dots, Y_m)p(ϕ,ψ1​,…,ψm​,Y1​,…,Ym​) that combines all components into a unified probabilistic model. Then inference can proceed by characterizing the posterior distribution p(ϕ,ψ1,…,ψm∣Y1,…,Ym)p(\phi, \psi_1, \dots, \psi_m | Y_1, \dots, Y_m)p(ϕ,ψ1​,…,ψm​∣Y1​,…,Ym​). The key distinction here is that all of the data Y1,…,YmY_1, \dots, Y_mY1​,…,Ym​ is used to inform the parameters across all components. The isolated component posterior pm(ϕ,ψm∣Ym)p_m(\phi, \psi_m|Y_m)pm​(ϕ,ψm​∣Ym​) might look quite different from p(ϕ,ψm∣Y1,…,Ym)p(\phi, \psi_m|Y_1, \dots, Y_m)p(ϕ,ψm​∣Y1​,…,Ym​) due to the influence of the other components.

On a final note before proceeding with the method, we emphasize the assumption that ϕ\phiϕ is the only link between the submodels. From a probabilistic standpoint, this implies that we will be considering joint distributions with the property that component-specific variables in any two distinct models are conditionally independent given the link parameter ϕ\phiϕ; symbolically, (ψm,Ym)⊥(ψℓ,Yℓ)∣ϕ,m≠ℓ.(3) (\psi_m, Y_m) \perp (\psi_\ell, Y_\ell) | \phi, \qquad m \neq \ell. \tag{3} (ψm​,Ym​)⊥(ψℓ​,Yℓ​)∣ϕ,m​=ℓ.(3)

Markov Combination

We start with the assumption that the submodels are consistent in the sense that they all imply the same prior distribution on the link parameter ϕ\phiϕ; i.e., p1(ϕ)=⋯=pM(ϕ).(4) p_1(\phi) = \cdots = p_M(\phi). \tag{4} p1​(ϕ)=⋯=pM​(ϕ).(4) The method of constructing a joint distribution under assumption (4) is referred to as Markov combination (Dawid and Lauritzen, 1993). This assumption makes the definition of a joint distribution relatively straightforward. Denoting the common prior on the link parameter by p(ϕ):=pm(ϕ)p(\phi) := p_m(\phi)p(ϕ):=pm​(ϕ), the Markov combination approach defines a joint distribution pcombp_{\text{comb}}pcomb​ by \begin{align} p_{\text{comb}}(\phi, \psi_1, \dots, \psi_M, Y_1, \dots, Y_M) &:= p_{\text{comb}}(\phi, \psi_1, \dots, \psi_M, Y_1, \dots, Y_M|\phi)p(\phi) \newline &:= p(\phi) \prod_{m=1}^{M} p_m(\psi_m, Y_m|\phi). \tag{5} \end{align} We emphasize the both of the above equalities are definitions, though both definitions are quite natural in this setting. The first ensures that the common prior p(ϕ)p(\phi)p(ϕ) is preserved by the joint distribution, while the second defines the conditional density (conditional on ϕ\phiϕ) using the conditional independence properties noted in (3). This ensures the submodel distributions pm(ϕ,ψm,Ym)p_m(\phi, \psi_m, Y_m)pm​(ϕ,ψm​,Ym​) are also preserved. Specifically, (5) satisfies pcomb(ϕ,ψm,Ym)=pm(ϕ,ψm,Ym),m=1,…,M.(6) p_{\text{comb}}(\phi, \psi_m, Y_m) = p_m(\phi, \psi_m, Y_m), \qquad m = 1, \dots, M. \tag{6} pcomb​(ϕ,ψm​,Ym​)=pm​(ϕ,ψm​,Ym​),m=1,…,M.(6) It will be useful to rewrite (5) as \begin{align} p_{\text{comb}}(\phi, \psi_1, \dots, \psi_M, Y_1, \dots, Y_M) &= p(\phi) \prod_{m=1}^{M} p_m(\psi_m, Y_m|\phi) \newline &= p(\phi) \prod_{m=1}^{M} \frac{p_m(\phi, \psi_m, Y_m)}{p(\phi)} \newline &= \frac{1}{p(\phi)^{M-1}} \prod_{m=1}^{M} p_m(\phi, \psi_m, Y_m), \tag{7} \end{align} which shows that pcombp_{\text{comb}}pcomb​ is just the product of the submodel distributions pmp_mpm​, normalized by p(ϕ)M−1p(\phi)^{M-1}p(ϕ)M−1 to account for the fact that the prior p(ϕ)p(\phi)p(ϕ) is multiplied MMM times in the product. From the expression (7), we may easily verify (6); letting ψ−m:=(ψ1,…,ψm−1,ψm+1,…,ψM)\psi_{-m} := (\psi_1, \dots, \psi_{m-1}, \psi_{m+1}, \dots, \psi_M)ψ−m​:=(ψ1​,…,ψm−1​,ψm+1​,…,ψM​) and similarly for Y−mY_{-m}Y−m​, we obtain \begin{align} p_{\text{comb}}(\phi, \psi_m, Y_m) &= \int p_{\text{comb}}(\phi, \psi_1, \dots, \psi_M, Y_1, \dots, Y_M) d\psi_{-m}dY_{-m} \newline &= \frac{1}{p(\phi)^{M-1}}p_m(\phi, \psi_m, Y_m) \prod_{\ell \neq m} \int p_m(\phi, \psi_m, Y_m) d\psi_\ell dY_\ell \newline &= \frac{1}{p(\phi)^{M-1}}p_m(\phi, \psi_m, Y_m) \prod_{\ell \neq m} p_\ell(\phi) \newline &= \frac{1}{p(\phi)^{M-1}}p_m(\phi, \psi_m, Y_m) p(\phi)^{M-1} \newline &= p_m(\phi, \psi_m, Y_m). \end{align}

While the definition (5) seems somewhat natural, one may wish for a more quantitative justification. To this end, Massa and Lauritzen (2010) show that pcombp_{\text{comb}}pcomb​ has maximal entropy among all distributions satisfying the MMM constraints (6). Loosely speaking, this tells us that pcombp_{\text{comb}}pcomb​ is the least constrained of all the distributions satisfying (6), a desirable property in the absence of additional knowledge on the relative merits of the submodels.

Markov Melding

Goudie et al (2019) consider propose a generalization of Markov combination to the setting where the marginals pm(ϕ)p_m(\phi)pm​(ϕ) may not be consistent across submodels. In this case, we can no longer simply pull out the common prior in the first line of definition (5). To address this, the authors’ propose first replacing the marginals pm(ϕ)p_m(\phi)pm​(ϕ) with a common “pooled” prior ppool(ϕ)p_{\text{pool}}(\phi)ppool​(ϕ). After performing this “marginal replacement”, Markov combination can then be applied with respect to the modified submodels.

Marginal Replacement

We first consider modifying the submodels to ensure they are consistent with respect to the marginal of the link parameter. The idea is to replace the original submodels pm(ϕ,ψm,Ym)=pm(ϕ)pm(ψm,Ym∣ϕ) p_m(\phi, \psi_m, Y_m) = p_m(\phi) p_m(\psi_m, Y_m | \phi) pm​(ϕ,ψm​,Ym​)=pm​(ϕ)pm​(ψm​,Ym​∣ϕ) with modifications that share a common ϕ\phiϕ-marginal: \begin{align} p_{\text{repl},m}(\phi, \psi_m, Y_m) &:= p_{\text{pool}}(\phi) p_m(\psi_m, Y_m | \phi) \tag{8} \newline &= \frac{p_{\text{pool}}(\phi)}{p_m(\phi)} p_m(\phi, \psi_m, Y_m). \tag{9} \end{align} We see in (8) that the submodel conditional (on ϕ\phiϕ) is unchanged by the marginal replacement. The expression (9) gives an alternative viewpoint, where we view the original joint submodel distribution pmp_mpm​ as re-weighted by some modification factor ppool(ϕ)/pm(ϕ)p_{\text{pool}}(\phi)/p_m(\phi)ppool​(ϕ)/pm​(ϕ). This, of course, begs the question of how to choose ppool(ϕ)p_{\text{pool}}(\phi)ppool​(ϕ). Naturally, we would hope this distribution adequately summarizes the original marginals p1(ϕ),…,pM(ϕ)p_1(\phi), \dots, p_M(\phi)p1​(ϕ),…,pM​(ϕ) in some sense. We put aside this question for the time being, and assume that we have fixed some pooled prior ppool(ϕ)p_{\text{pool}}(\phi)ppool​(ϕ). Given that a common prior ppool(ϕ)p_{\text{pool}}(\phi)ppool​(ϕ) has been chosen, Goudie et al (2019) provides some justification for the definition (9): prepl,m(ϕ,ψm,Ym)=argminq∈QDKL(q∣∣pm), p_{\text{repl},m}(\phi, \psi_m, Y_m) = \text{argmin}_{q \in \mathcal{Q}} \text{D}_{\text{KL}}(q || p_m), prepl,m​(ϕ,ψm​,Ym​)=argminq∈Q​DKL​(q∣∣pm​), where Q={q(ϕ,ψm,Ym)∣q(ϕ)=ppool(ϕ) ∀ϕ}. \mathcal{Q} = \left\{q(\phi, \psi_m, Y_m) | q(\phi) = p_{\text{pool}}(\phi) \ \forall \phi \right\}. Q={q(ϕ,ψm​,Ym​)∣q(ϕ)=ppool​(ϕ) ∀ϕ}. In words, the marginally replaced distribution minimizes the KL-divergence with respect to pmp_mpm​ over all distributions with ϕ\phiϕ-marginals equal to ppool(ϕ)p_{\text{pool}}(\phi)ppool​(ϕ).

Markov Combination with respect to the modified submodels

We can now apply Markov combination with respect to the modified submodels prepl,1,…,prepl,Mp_{\text{repl},1}, \dots, p_{\text{repl},M}prepl,1​,…,prepl,M​. Following (5), define \begin{align} p_{\text{meld}}(\phi, \psi_1, \dots, \psi_M, Y_1, \dots, Y_M) &:= p_{\text{pool}}(\phi) \prod_{m=1}^{M} p_{\text{repl},m}(\psi_m, Y_m|\phi) \newline &= p_{\text{pool}}(\phi) \prod_{m=1}^{M} p_{m}(\psi_m, Y_m|\phi), \tag{10} \end{align} where the second equality uses the fact that marginal replacement preserves the conditionals (see (9)). We can alternatively expand (10) as pmeld(ϕ,ψ1,…,ψM,Y1,…,YM)=ppool(ϕ)∏m=1Mpm(ϕ,ψm,Ym)pm(ϕ),(11) p_{\text{meld}}(\phi, \psi_1, \dots, \psi_M, Y_1, \dots, Y_M) = p_{\text{pool}}(\phi) \prod_{m=1}^{M} \frac{p_{m}(\phi, \psi_m, Y_m)}{p_m(\phi)}, \tag{11} pmeld​(ϕ,ψ1​,…,ψM​,Y1​,…,YM​)=ppool​(ϕ)m=1∏M​pm​(ϕ)pm​(ϕ,ψm​,Ym​)​,(11) which provides a direct comparison to (7). All of the facts noted for Markov combination still apply here, but now with respect to the marginally replaced models prepl,mp_{\text{repl},m}prepl,m​, not the original submodels. In particular, we have that pmeld(ϕ,ψm,Ym)=prepl,m(ϕ,ψm,Ym),m=1,…,M,(12) p_{\text{meld}}(\phi, \psi_m, Y_m) = p_{\text{repl},m}(\phi, \psi_m, Y_m), \qquad m = 1, \dots, M, \tag{12} pmeld​(ϕ,ψm​,Ym​)=prepl,m​(ϕ,ψm​,Ym​),m=1,…,M,(12) but in general prepl,m(ϕ,ψm,Ym)≠pm(ϕ,ψm,Ym),(13) p_{\text{repl},m}(\phi, \psi_m, Y_m) \neq p_{m}(\phi, \psi_m, Y_m), \tag{13} prepl,m​(ϕ,ψm​,Ym​)​=pm​(ϕ,ψm​,Ym​),(13) meaning that p(meld)p(\text{meld})p(meld) does not preserve the submodel joint distributions. However, p(meld)p(\text{meld})p(meld) still does enjoy the conditional preservation property: pmeld(ψm,Ym∣ϕ)=pm(ψm,Ym∣ϕ),m=1,…,M,(14) p_{\text{meld}}(\psi_m, Y_m|\phi) = p_{m}(\psi_m, Y_m|\phi), \qquad m = 1, \dots, M, \tag{14} pmeld​(ψm​,Ym​∣ϕ)=pm​(ψm​,Ym​∣ϕ),m=1,…,M,(14) which should be somewhat intuitive given that the marginal replacement method does not modify the conditionals (see (8)). To verify this, apply (11) to see that \begin{align} p_{\text{meld}}(\psi_1, \dots, \psi_M, Y_1, \dots, Y_M|\phi) &= \frac{p_{\text{meld}}(\phi, \psi_1, \dots, \psi_M, Y_1, \dots, Y_M)}{p_{\text{pool}}(\phi)} \newline &= \frac{1}{p_{\text{pool}}(\phi)} p_{\text{pool}}(\phi) \prod_{m=1}^{M} \frac{p_{m}(\phi, \psi_m, Y_m)}{p_m(\phi)} \newline &= \prod_{m=1}^{M} p_{m}(\psi_m, Y_m|\phi). \tag{15} \end{align} We see from (15) that pmeldp_{\text{meld}}pmeld​ still preserved the conditional independence structure summarized in (3), and that (14) falls out as a result.

Deterministic Variables

Goudie et al (2019) also consider the scenario where the link variable ϕ\phiϕ may appear in a submodel as a deterministic function of the other submodel variables, rather than being explicitly defined by the joint distribution pmp_mpm​. In particular, suppose one of the submodels takes the form \begin{align} &p_{\theta}(\theta, \psi, Y), &&\phi = f(\theta), \tag{16} \end{align} for some deterministic, differentiable map f:Rℓ→Rkf: \mathbb{R}^{\ell} \to \mathbb{R}^kf:Rℓ→Rk with k≤ℓk \leq \ellk≤ℓ. If k=ℓk=\ellk=ℓ and fff is invertible, then the density of ϕ\phiϕ is given by the change-of-variables formula pϕ(ϕ)=∣Df−1(ϕ)∣pθ(f−1(ϕ)),(17) p_{\phi}(\phi) = |Df^{-1}(\phi)| p_{\theta}(f^{-1}(\phi)), \tag{17} pϕ​(ϕ)=∣Df−1(ϕ)∣pθ​(f−1(ϕ)),(17) where ∣Df−1(ϕ)∣|Df^{-1}(\phi)|∣Df−1(ϕ)∣ denotes the determinant of the Jacobian Df−1Df^{-1}Df−1 evaluated at ϕ\phiϕ; Df−1(ϕ)∈Rℓ×kDf^{-1}(\phi) \in \mathbb{R}^{\ell \times k}Df−1(ϕ)∈Rℓ×k. Next, consider the case where k<ℓk < \ellk<ℓ. Here, we assume that fff can be extended to an invertible function f~:Rℓ→Rℓ\tilde{f}: \mathbb{R}^{\ell} \to \mathbb{R}^{\ell}f~​:Rℓ→Rℓ of the form \begin{align} \tilde{f}(\theta) &= \begin{bmatrix} f(\theta) \newline g(\theta) \end{bmatrix}, &&g: \mathbb{R}^{\ell} \to \mathbb{R}^{\ell-k}. \tag{18} \end{align} The density of (ϕ,ϕ~)(\phi, \tilde{\phi})(ϕ,ϕ~​) induced by the distribution on θ\thetaθ is then given by pϕ(ϕ,ϕ~)=∣Df~−1(ϕ,ϕ~)∣pθ(f~−1(ϕ,ϕ~)).(19) p_{\phi}(\phi,\tilde{\phi}) = |D\tilde{f}^{-1}(\phi, \tilde{\phi})| p_{\theta}(\tilde{f}^{-1}(\phi, \tilde{\phi})). \tag{19} pϕ​(ϕ,ϕ~​)=∣Df~​−1(ϕ,ϕ~​)∣pθ​(f~​−1(ϕ,ϕ~​)).(19) Similarly, we can consider the change-of-variables for the complete joint distribution pϕ(ϕ,ϕ~,ψ,Y)=∣Df~−1(ϕ,ϕ~)∣pθ(f~−1(ϕ,ϕ~),ψ,Y).(20) p_{\phi}(\phi, \tilde{\phi}, \psi, Y) = |D\tilde{f}^{-1}(\phi, \tilde{\phi})| p_{\theta}(\tilde{f}^{-1}(\phi, \tilde{\phi}), \psi, Y). \tag{20} pϕ​(ϕ,ϕ~​,ψ,Y)=∣Df~​−1(ϕ,ϕ~​)∣pθ​(f~​−1(ϕ,ϕ~​),ψ,Y).(20) We can then obtain the desired submodel distribution over (ϕ,ψ,Y)(\phi,\psi,Y)(ϕ,ψ,Y) by marginalizing the nuisance parameter ϕ~\tilde{\phi}ϕ~​: p(ϕ,ψ,Y):=∫pϕ(ϕ,ϕ~,ψ,Y)dϕ~.(21) p(\phi, \psi, Y) := \int p_{\phi}(\phi, \tilde{\phi}, \psi, Y) d\tilde{\phi}. \tag{21} p(ϕ,ψ,Y):=∫pϕ​(ϕ,ϕ~​,ψ,Y)dϕ~​.(21) One concern here is that this procedure will produce difference results for different choices of the extension function g(⋅)g(\cdot)g(⋅). Goudie et al (2019) show that this is not the case.

Inference

We now consider algorithmic methods for characterizing the posterior distribution pmeld(ϕ,ψ1,…,ψM∣Y1,…,YM)∝ppool(ϕ)∏m=1Mpm(ϕ,ψm,Ym)pm(ϕ).(22) p_{\text{meld}}(\phi, \psi_1, \dots, \psi_M|Y_1, \dots, Y_M) \propto p_{\text{pool}}(\phi) \prod_{m=1}^{M} \frac{p_{m}(\phi, \psi_m, Y_m)}{p_m(\phi)}. \tag{22} pmeld​(ϕ,ψ1​,…,ψM​∣Y1​,…,YM​)∝ppool​(ϕ)m=1∏M​pm​(ϕ)pm​(ϕ,ψm​,Ym​)​.(22) So long as the joint density pmeldp_{\text{meld}}pmeld​ can be evaluated pointwise, then one can consider applying a general-purpose inference algorithm (e.g., Metropolis-Hastings) in the typical fashion. Goudie et al (2019) consider some specific MCMC algorithms that are tailored to the specific structure in the density (22). Throughout this section we will utilize the shorthand ψ1:ℓ:=(ψ1,…,ψℓ)\psi_{1:\ell} := (\psi_1, \dots, \psi_\ell)ψ1:ℓ​:=(ψ1​,…,ψℓ​) and y1:ℓ:=(y1,…,yℓ)y_{1:\ell} := (y_1, \dots, y_\ell)y1:ℓ​:=(y1​,…,yℓ​) for brevity. Here, ymy_mym​ denotes a particular fixed realization of the data random variable YmY_mYm​. In considering Metropolis-Hastings (MH) algorithms, we will write ψm∗\psi_m^*ψm∗​ and ψm\psi_mψm​ to indicate the proposed and current values, respectively, of the mthm^{\text{th}}mth submodel parameter (and likewise for ϕ∗\phi^*ϕ∗).

Metropolis-within-Gibbs

The structure of (22) suggests updating the component-specific parameters ψm\psi_mψm​ one at a time, and hence a Metropolis-within-Gibbs (MwG) scheme.

ψm\psi_mψm​ update

We first consider updating ψm\psi_mψm​ conditional on all other parameters. This implies a MH update with respect to the target density pmeld(ψm∣Y1:M,ϕ,ψ−m)p_{\text{meld}}(\psi_m|Y_{1:M}, \phi, \psi_{-m})pmeld​(ψm​∣Y1:M​,ϕ,ψ−m​). The standard MH update consists of the following steps:

  1. Propose a new value: ψm∗∼q(ψm∗∣ψm)\psi_m^* \sim q(\psi_m^*|\psi_m)ψm∗​∼q(ψm∗​∣ψm​).
  2. Accept the new value with probability:

α(ψm∗∣ψm):=min⁡(1,r(ψm∗∣ψm)),(22) \alpha(\psi_m^* |\psi_m) := \min\left(1, r(\psi_m^*|\psi_m) \right), \tag{22} α(ψm∗​∣ψm​):=min(1,r(ψm∗​∣ψm​)),(22) where r(ψm∗∣ψm):=pmeld(ψm∗∣Y1:M,ϕ,ψ−m)pmeld(ψm∣Y1:M,ϕ,ψ−m)⋅q(ψm∣ψm∗)q(ψm∗∣ψm).(23) r(\psi_m^*|\psi_m) := \frac{p_{\text{meld}}(\psi_m^*|Y_{1:M}, \phi, \psi_{-m})}{p_{\text{meld}}(\psi_m|Y_{1:M}, \phi, \psi_{-m})} \cdot \frac{q(\psi_m|\psi_m^*)}{q(\psi_m^*|\psi_m)}. \tag{23} r(ψm∗​∣ψm​):=pmeld​(ψm​∣Y1:M​,ϕ,ψ−m​)pmeld​(ψm∗​∣Y1:M​,ϕ,ψ−m​)​⋅q(ψm∗​∣ψm​)q(ψm​∣ψm∗​)​.(23) Here, qqq is the proposal density, with q(ψm∗∣ψm)q(\psi_m^*|\psi_m)q(ψm∗​∣ψm​) denoting the density of proposing ψm∗\psi_m^*ψm∗​. The acceptance ratio r(ψm∗∣ψm)r(\psi_m^*|\psi_m)r(ψm∗​∣ψm​) simplifies considerably in this case, since:

\begin{align} \frac{p_{\text{meld}}(\psi_m^|y_{1:M}, \phi, \psi_{-m})}{p_{\text{meld}}(\psi_m|y_{1:M}, \phi, \psi_{-m})} &\propto \frac{p_{\text{meld}}(\psi_m^, y_{1:M}, \phi, \psi_{-m})}{p_{\text{meld}}(\psi_m, y_{1:M}, \phi, \psi_{-m})} \end{align}

where we have simply plugged in expression (11) and cancelled terms. Notice that the resulting expression, (24), only contains terms related to the the mthm^{\text{th}}mth submodel. In other words, (24) is the exact density ratio we would obtain if considering a MwG scheme applied only to the mthm^{\text{th}}mth submodel in isolation.

ϕ\phiϕ update

We next consider updating the link parameter, conditional on all component-specific parameters. We similarly consider some proposal ϕ∗∼q(ϕ∗∣ϕ)\phi^* \sim q(\phi^*|\phi)ϕ∗∼q(ϕ∗∣ϕ), in which case the density ratio becomes pmeld(ϕ∗∣y1:M,ψ1:M)pmeld(ϕ∣y1:M,ψ1:M)=ppool(ϕ∗)ppool(ϕ)∏m=1Mpm(ϕ∗,ψm,ym)pm(ϕ,ψm,ym)q(ϕ∣ϕ∗)q(ϕ∗∣ϕ).(25) \frac{p_{\text{meld}}(\phi^*|y_{1:M}, \psi_{1:M})}{p_{\text{meld}}(\phi|y_{1:M}, \psi_{1:M})} = \frac{p_{\text{pool}}(\phi^*)}{p_{\text{pool}}(\phi)} \prod_{m=1}^{M} \frac{p_m(\phi^*, \psi_m, y_m)}{p_m(\phi, \psi_m, y_m)} \frac{q(\phi|\phi^*)}{q(\phi^*|\phi)}. \tag{25} pmeld​(ϕ∣y1:M​,ψ1:M​)pmeld​(ϕ∗∣y1:M​,ψ1:M​)​=ppool​(ϕ)ppool​(ϕ∗)​m=1∏M​pm​(ϕ,ψm​,ym​)pm​(ϕ∗,ψm​,ym​)​q(ϕ∗∣ϕ)q(ϕ∣ϕ∗)​.(25)

entry.title: Ensemble Kalman Methodology for Inverse Problems

link.title: Ensemble Kalman Methodology for Inverse Problems

entry.content:
In this post we provide a brief introduction to how ideas related to the Ensemble Kalman Filter (EnKF) can be applied to approximate the posterior distribution of a Bayesian inverse problem. While the EnKF is traditionally applied to time-varying dynamical systems, we show how to introduce artificial dynamics into an otherwise static inverse problem in order to port the EnKF methodology to the inverse problem setting. After defining the inverse problem formulation, we start simply by demonstrating how combining joint Gaussian assumptions with Monte Carlo approximations can provide a means of approximate Bayesian inference. We then generalize this idea by considering a sequence of such joint Gaussian approximations, providing a clear link to the EnKF. These methods are characterized by a finite sequence of updates that map the prior distribution to an (approximate) posterior distribution. We then generalize further by considering a slight adjustment to the EnKF update rules such that the resulting algorithms consist of an infinite sequence of updates. Practical algorithms are defined by truncating after a finite number of steps. Algorithms falling into this class have come to be known as ensemble Kalman inversion (EKI), and have gained much recent interest. We conclude by briefly highlighting connections to measure transport.

Setup: Bayesian Inverse Problems

In this post, we consider the inverse problem formulation \begin{align} y &= \mathcal{G}(u) + \epsilon \tag{1} \newline u &\sim \pi_0 \newline \epsilon &\sim \mathcal{N}(0, \Sigma), \end{align} whereby the task is to recover a parameter u∈Uu \in \mathcal{U}u∈U from noisy observations y∈Rpy \in \mathbb{R}^py∈Rp resulting from the mapping of uuu through a forward model G:U→Rp\mathcal{G}: \mathcal{U} \to \mathbb{R}^pG:U→Rp. The Bayesian approach to inverse problems treats uuu as a random variable, such that the statistical model (1) defines a joint distribution over the random vector (u,y)(u,y)(u,y). The solution of the Bayesian inverse problem is then defined to be the conditional distribution of u∣yu|yu∣y; i.e., the posterior distribution. The model (1) defines the joint distribution by separately defining the two components in the product p(u,y)=p(y∣u)p(u).(2) p(u,y) = p(y|u)p(u). \tag{2} p(u,y)=p(y∣u)p(u).(2) We note that the model (1) implicitly assumes a priori independence between the noise ϵ\epsilonϵ and parameter uuu. The first term p(y∣u)p(y|u)p(y∣u) in (2), when viewed as a function of uuu is called the likelihood. For convenience later on, we will introduce notation for (up to a constant) the negative log-likelihood Φ(u):=−log⁡p(u∣y)+C,(3) \Phi(u) := -\log p(u|y) + C, \tag{3} Φ(u):=−logp(u∣y)+C,(3) which is sometimes also called the potential or model-data misfit. Throughout most of this post, we restrict to the choice of a Gaussian likelihood (as in (1)), in which case \begin{align} -\log p(y|u) &= -\log \mathcal{N}(y|\mathcal{G}(u),\Sigma) \newline &= \frac{1}{2}\log\det(2\pi \Sigma) + \frac{1}{2}\lVert y - \mathcal{G}(u)\rVert^2_{\Sigma} \tag{4} \end{align} and \begin{align} &\Phi(u) = \frac{1}{2}\lVert y - \mathcal{G}(u)\rVert^2_{\Sigma}, &&C = \frac{1}{2}\log\det(2\pi \Sigma). \tag{5} \end{align} As above, we will use the notation ∥x∥A2:=⟨x,x⟩A:=x⊤A−1x(5) \lVert x \rVert^2_A := \langle x, x\rangle_A := x^\top A^{-1}x \tag{5} ∥x∥A2​:=⟨x,x⟩A​:=x⊤A−1x(5) to denote the Euclidean norm weighted by the inverse of a positive definite matrix AAA. The second term in (2), p(u)p(u)p(u), is called the prior. In this post, we will restrict to the setting U⊆Rd\mathcal{U} \subseteq \mathbb{R}^dU⊆Rd and assume that the prior distribution is given by a density π0(u)\pi_0(u)π0​(u). We denote the resulting posterior density (the density describing the distribution of u∣yu|yu∣y) by π(u)\pi(u)π(u). The methods discussed below can be generalized to settings where U\mathcal{U}U may be a function space; e.g., the prior distribution may be given by a Gaussian process.

Background: Joint Gaussian Conditioning

Joint Gaussian Assumption

We now begin by considering approximation of the posterior u∣yu|yu∣y by way of a certain Gaussian approximation. In particular, we will assume that (u,y)(u,y)(u,y) are jointly Gaussian distributed, in which case standard Gaussian conditioning identities can be implied to yield an approximation of u∣yu|yu∣y. Given that conditionals of Gaussians are also Gaussian, this approach produces a Gaussian approximation to the posterior u∣yu|yu∣y. However, borrowing an idea from EnKF methodology, we will consider a slight modification with the ability to produce non-Gaussian approximations. To avoid notational confusion between exact and approximate distributions, we will denote by (u^,y^)(\hat{u}, \hat{y})(u^,y^​) the random variables defining the joint Gaussian approximation. The Gaussian assumption thus takes the form \begin{align} \begin{bmatrix} \hat{u} \newline \hat{y} \end{bmatrix} \sim \mathcal{N}\left( \begin{bmatrix} \overline{u} \newline \overline{y} \end{bmatrix}, \begin{bmatrix} \hat{C} & \hat{C}^{uy} \newline
\hat{C}^{yu} & \hat{C}^{y} \end{bmatrix} \right) \tag{6} \end{align} where the moments u‾\overline{u}u, y‾\overline{y}y​, C^\hat{C}C^, C^y\hat{C}^yC^y, and C^uy\hat{C}^{uy}C^uy defining this approximation are quantities that we must specify. We use the notation C^yu:=C^uy\hat{C}^{yu} := \hat{C}^{uy}C^yu:=C^uy. Note that if the forward model G\mathcal{G}G is linear and the prior distribution π0\pi_0π0​ is Gaussian, then the joint Gaussian approximation (6) is actually exact, and the moments can be computed in closed-form. In other words, with the moments properly defined, (u^,y^)=d(u,y)(\hat{u},\hat{y}) \overset{d}{=} (u,y)(u^,y^​)=d(u,y) and therefore (u^∣y^)=d(u∣y)(\hat{u}|\hat{y}) \overset{d}{=} (u|y)(u^∣y^​)=d(u∣y); that is, the posterior approximation is exact. This special case is typically referred to as the linear Gaussian setting, which I discuss in depth in this this post. When G\mathcal{G}G is nonlinear and/or π0\pi_0π0​ is non-Gaussian, then (6) will truly be an approximation and the above equalities will not hold.

In the following subsections, we briefly review some properties of joint Gaussians and their conditional distributions. We work with the joint distribution (6), assuming the means and covariances are known. With the necessary background established, we then discuss practical algorithms for estimating these moments and producing approximations of u∣yu|yu∣y.

Gaussian Conditional Moments

Regardless of whether or not we are truly in the linear Gaussian setting, let us suppose that we have constructed the joint distribution (6). Using standard facts about Gaussian distributions, we know the conditional is also Gaussian u^∣[y^=y]∼N(m^∗,C^∗),(7) \hat{u}|[\hat{y}=y] \sim \mathcal{N}(\hat{m}_*, \hat{C}_*), \tag{7} u^∣[y^​=y]∼N(m^∗​,C^∗​),(7) with moments given by

m^∗=u‾+C^uy[C^y]−1(y−y‾)(8) \hat{m}_* = \overline{u} + \hat{C}^{uy}[\hat{C}^y]^{-1}(y - \overline{y}) \tag{8} m^∗​=u+C^uy[C^y]−1(y−y​)(8) C^∗=C^−C^uy[C^y]−1C^yu.(9) \hat{C}_* = \hat{C} - \hat{C}^{uy}[\hat{C}^y]^{-1}\hat{C}^{yu}. \tag{9} C^∗​=C^−C^uy[C^y]−1C^yu.(9)

Gaussian Conditional Simulation

As an alternative to explicitly computing the conditional moments (8) and (9), we can consider a Monte Carlo representation of u^∣y^\hat{u}|\hat{y}u^∣y^​. The conditional distribution can be directly simulated (without computing (8) and (9)) using the fact (u^∣[y^=y])=du^+C^uy[C^y]−1(y−y^),(10) (\hat{u}|[\hat{y}=y]) \overset{d}{=} \hat{u} + \hat{C}^{uy}[\hat{C}^y]^{-1}(y-\hat{y}), \tag{10} (u^∣[y^​=y])=du^+C^uy[C^y]−1(y−y^​),(10) which can be quickly verified by computing the mean and covariance of each side. Note that the randomness in the righthand side is inherited from the random variables u^\hat{u}u^ and y^\hat{y}y^​, while yyy here is viewed as a specific realization of the data (and is thus non-random). The result (10), known as Matheron’s Rule, provides the basis for the following algorithm to draw independent samples from the conditional distribution u^∣[y^=y]\hat{u}|[\hat{y}=y]u^∣[y^​=y].

Gaussian Conditional Simulation via Matheron's Rule.
Independent samples u^∗(1),…,u^∗(J)\hat{u}_*^{(1)}, \dots, \hat{u}_*^{(J)}u^∗(1)​,…,u^∗(J)​ can be simulated from the distribution u^∣[y^=y]\hat{u}|[\hat{y}=y]u^∣[y^​=y] by repeating the following procedure for each j=1,…,Jj=1,\dots,Jj=1,…,J:

1. Draw independent samples u^(j)\hat{u}^{(j)}u^(j) and y^(j)\hat{y}^{(j)}y^​(j) from the marginal distributions of u^\hat{u}u^ and y^\hat{y}y^​, respectively. That is, \begin{align} &\hat{u}^{(j)} \sim \mathcal{N}(\overline{u},\hat{C}) &&\hat{y}^{(j)} \sim \mathcal{N}(\overline{y},\hat{C}^y). \tag{11} \end{align} 2. Return u^∗(j):=u^(j)+C^uy[C^y]−1(y−y^(j)).(12) \hat{u}^{(j)}_* := \hat{u}^{(j)} + \hat{C}^{uy}[\hat{C}^y]^{-1}(y-\hat{y}^{(j)}). \tag{12} u^∗(j)​:=u^(j)+C^uy[C^y]−1(y−y^​(j)).(12)

Posterior Approximation Algorithm

Up to this point, we have not discussed the choice of the moments defining the joint Gaussian approximation (6). We now provide these definitions, leading to concrete algorithms for posterior approximation. We will adopt a Monte Carlo strategy by sampling independently from the true joint distribution (u,y)(u,y)(u,y) defined by (1); i.e., (u(j),y(j))∼p(u,y)(u^{(j)}, y^{(j)}) \sim p(u,y)(u(j),y(j))∼p(u,y). We next compute the empirical means and covariances of these random draws and insert them into the joint Gaussian approximation (6). The below subsection focuses on the estimation of these moments, which we will then follow by utilizing the above Gaussian conditioning results to derive various approximations of u∣yu|yu∣y.

Estimating the Gaussian Moments

The first step in our approach requires generating the prior ensemble {(u(j),ϵ(j))},j=1,…,J(13) \{(u^{(j)}, \epsilon^{(j)})\}, \qquad j = 1, \dots, J \tag{13} {(u(j),ϵ(j))},j=1,…,J(13) constructed by sampling according to model (1); i.e., \begin{align} &u^{(j)} \sim \pi_0, &&\epsilon^{(j)} \sim \mathcal{N}(0, \Sigma). \tag{14} \end{align} We now consider estimating the first two moments of this joint distribution. Starting with the uuu marginal, we define the sample estimates \begin{align} \overline{u} &:= \frac{1}{J}\sum_{j=1}^{J} u^{(j)} \tag{15} \newline \hat{C} &:= \frac{1}{J-1}\sum_{j=1}^{J} (u^{(j)}-\overline{u})(u^{(j)}-\overline{u})^\top. \tag{16} \end{align} Alternatively, if the prior π0\pi_0π0​ takes the form of a well-known distribution, then we can simply set u‾\overline{u}u and/or C^\hat{C}C^ to the known moments of this distribution. We can likewise consider such mean and covariance estimates for the y^\hat{y}y^​ portion of (6), defined with respect to the ensemble {y(j)}j=1J,y(j):=G(u(j))+ϵ(j).(17) \{y^{(j)}\}_{j=1}^{J}, \qquad\qquad y^{(j)} := \mathcal{G}(u^{(j)}) + \epsilon^{(j)}. \tag{17} {y(j)}j=1J​,y(j):=G(u(j))+ϵ(j).(17) However, we can simplify matters a bit by performing part of the calculations analytically, owing to the simple additive Gaussian error structure. Noting that under (1) we have \begin{align} \mathbb{E}[y] &= \mathbb{E}[\mathcal{G}(u) + \epsilon] = \mathbb{E}[\mathcal{G}(u)] \tag{18} \newline \text{Cov}[y] &= \text{Cov}[\mathcal{G}(u) + \epsilon] = \text{Cov}[\mathcal{G}(u)] + \text{Cov}[\epsilon] = \text{Cov}[\mathcal{G}(u)] + \Sigma, \tag{19} \end{align} we can focus our efforts on substituting sample-based estimates for the first term in both (18) and (19). Doing so yields, \begin{align} \overline{y} &:= \frac{1}{J} \sum_{j=1}^{J} \mathcal{G}(u^{(j)}) \tag{20} \newline \hat{C}^y &:= \frac{1}{J-1} \sum_{j=1}^{J} (\mathcal{G}(u^{(j)})-\overline{y})(\mathcal{G}(u^{(j)})-\overline{y})^\top + \Sigma. \tag{21} \end{align} We similarly define the last remaining quantity C^uy\hat{C}^{uy}C^uy by noting that Cov[u,y]=Cov[u,G(u)+ϵ]=Cov[u,G(u)]+Cov[u,ϵ]=Cov[u,G(u)].(22) \text{Cov}[u,y] = \text{Cov}[u,\mathcal{G}(u)+\epsilon] = \text{Cov}[u,\mathcal{G}(u)] + \text{Cov}[u,\epsilon] = \text{Cov}[u,\mathcal{G}(u)]. \tag{22} Cov[u,y]=Cov[u,G(u)+ϵ]=Cov[u,G(u)]+Cov[u,ϵ]=Cov[u,G(u)].(22) We thus consider the estimator C^uy:=1J−1∑j=1J(u(j)−u‾)(G(u(j))−y‾)⊤.(23) \hat{C}^{uy} := \frac{1}{J-1} \sum_{j=1}^{J} (u^{(j)}-\overline{u})(\mathcal{G}(u^{(j)})-\overline{y})^\top. \tag{23} C^uy:=J−11​j=1∑J​(u(j)−u)(G(u(j))−y​)⊤.(23)

Gaussian Approximations

At this point, we have obtained the joint approximation (6) derived by computing the sample moments as described in the previous subsection. The question is now how best to use this joint approximation in approximating the true posterior. The most straightforward approach is to simply define our approximate posterior to be u^∣[y^=y]\hat{u}|[\hat{y}=y]u^∣[y^​=y], the Gaussian conditional. This conditional is available in closed-form and is defined in equations (7), (8), and (9). Suppose, for whatever reason, we are only interested in a sample-based representation of this Gaussian conditional. In this case, we can apply the algorithm summarized in (11) and (12) based on Matheron’s Rule. Explicitly, we construct an approximate posterior ensemble {u^∗(j)}j=1J′\{\hat{u}_*^{(j)}\}_{j=1}^{J^\prime}{u^∗(j)​}j=1J′​ via the update equation in (12), u^∗(j):=u^(j)+C^uy[C^y]−1(y−y^(j)),(24) \hat{u}^{(j)}_* := \hat{u}^{(j)} + \hat{C}^{uy}[\hat{C}^y]^{-1}(y-\hat{y}^{(j)}), \tag{24} u^∗(j)​:=u^(j)+C^uy[C^y]−1(y−y^​(j)),(24) for j=1,…,J′j = 1, \dots, J^\primej=1,…,J′. At this point we should be quite clear about the definition of each term in (24). The mean and covariance estimates appearing in this expression are all derived from the ensemble {(u(j),ϵ(j))}j=1J\{(u^{(j)}, \epsilon^{(j)})\}_{j=1}^{J}{(u(j),ϵ(j))}j=1J​ sampled from the true joint distribution implied by (1). On the other hand, {u^(j),y^(j)}j=1J′\{\hat{u}^{(j)}, \hat{y}^{(j)}\}_{j=1}^{J^\prime}{u^(j),y^​(j)}j=1J′​ are samples from the approximate joint distribution defined in (6). This is simply an exact implementation of Matheron’s rule under the joint distribution (6); i.e., the resulting ensemble {u^∗(j)}j=1J′\{\hat{u}^{(j)}_*\}_{j=1}^{J^\prime}{u^∗(j)​}j=1J′​ contains iid samples from u^∣[y^=y]\hat{u}|[\hat{y}=y]u^∣[y^​=y]. If it seems odd to dwell on this point, we note that we are primarily doing so to provide motivation for the alternative method discussed below.

Non-Gaussian Approximation via EnKF Update

As discussed above, a direct application of Matheron’s rule to (6) results in an ensemble of samples from a Gaussian distribution, which we interpret as a sample-based approximation to the true posterior. We now consider constructing the ensemble {u^∗(j)}j=1J\{\hat{u}_*^{(j)}\}_{j=1}^{J}{u^∗(j)​}j=1J​ via the slightly different update rule u^∗(j):=u(j)+C^uy[C^y]−1(y−y(j)),(25) \hat{u}^{(j)}_* := u^{(j)} + \hat{C}^{uy}[\hat{C}^y]^{-1}(y-y^{(j)}), \tag{25} u^∗(j)​:=u(j)+C^uy[C^y]−1(y−y(j)),(25) for j=1,…,Jj = 1, \dots, Jj=1,…,J. This is precisely the update equation used in the analysis (i.e., update) step of the EnKF, so we refer to (25) as the EnKF update. The only difference from (24) is that we have replaced the samples (u^(j),y^(j))(\hat{u}^{(j)},\hat{y}^{(j)})(u^(j),y^​(j)) from (6) with the samples (u(j),y(j))(u^{(j)}, y^{(j)})(u(j),y(j)) from the true joint distribution, as defined in (14) and (17). In other words, we now utilize the samples from the initial ensemble (the same samples used to compute the mean and covariance estimates). Thus, equation (25) can be viewed as a particle-by-particle update to the initial ensemble, {u(j)}j=1J↦{u^∗(j)}j=1J.(26) \{u^{(j)}\}_{j=1}^{J} \mapsto \{\hat{u}^{(j)}_*\}_{j=1}^{J}. \tag{26} {u(j)}j=1J​↦{u^∗(j)​}j=1J​.(26) The update (25) is somewhat heuristic, and it is difficult to assess the properties of the updated ensemble. Given that the initial ensemble will not in general constitute samples from a Gaussian (since p(u,y)p(u,y)p(u,y) is in general non-Gaussian), then the updated ensemble will also generally be non-Gaussian distributed. If the inverse problem (1) is linear Gaussian, then the updates (24) and (25) are essentially equivalent. Beyond this special case, the hope is that the use of the true prior samples in (25) will better approximate non-Gaussianity in the posterior distribution, as opposed to the Gaussian approximation implied by (24). The EnKF update can alternatively be justified from an optimization perspective, which we won’t discuss here; see my post on the EnKF for details. We conclude this section by summarizing the final algorithm.

Posterior Approximation via EnKF Update.

1. Generate the initial ensembles {u(j)}j=1J\{u^{(j)}\}_{j=1}^{J}{u(j)}j=1J​ and {G(u(j))}j=1J\{\mathcal{G}(u^{(j)})\}_{j=1}^{J}{G(u(j))}j=1J​, where u(j)∼π0u^{(j)} \sim \pi_0u(j)∼π0​.
2. Compute the sample estimates u‾\overline{u}u, y‾\overline{y}y​, C^\hat{C}C^, C^y\hat{C}^yC^y, and C^uy\hat{C}^{uy}C^uy as defined in (20)-(23).
3. Return the updated ensemble {u^∗(j)}j=1J\{\hat{u}^{(j)}_*\}_{j=1}^{J}{u^∗(j)​}j=1J​ by applying the EnKF update \begin{align} \hat{u}^{(j)}_* &:= u^{(j)} + \hat{C}^{uy}[\hat{C}^y]^{-1}(y-y^{(j)}), &&y^{(j)} \sim \mathcal{N}(\mathcal{G}(u^{(j)}), \Sigma). \tag{27} \end{align}

Artificial Dynamics

As noted above, the approximation algorithm summarized in (27) can be viewed as performing an iteration of the EnKF algorithm. In this section, we take this idea further by encoding the structure of the inverse problem (1) in a dynamical system. Once these artificial dynamics are introduced, we can then consider applying standard algorithms for Bayesian estimation of time-evolving systems (e.g., the EnKF) to solve the inverse problem. We emphasize that (1), the original problem we are trying to solve, is static. The dynamics we introduce here are purely artificial, introduced for the purpose of making a mathematical connection with the vast field of time-varying systems. This allows us to port methods that have demonstrated success in the time-varying domain to our current problem of interest.

Prior-to-Posterior Map in Finite Time

We start by generically considering how to construct a sequence of probability distributions that maps from the prior π0\pi_0π0​ to the posterior π\piπ in a finite number of steps. We will find it convenient to write the likelihood with respect to the potential Φ(u)\Phi(u)Φ(u) defined in (3), such that the posterior distribution solving (1) is given by

\begin{align} \pi(u) &= \frac{1}{Z} \pi_0(u)\exp(-\Phi(u)), &&Z = \int \pi_0(u)\exp(-\Phi(u)) du. \tag{28} \end{align}

The following result describes a likelihood tempering approach to constructing the desired sequence of densities.

Prior-to-Posterior Sequence of Densities.

For a positive integer KKK, define the sequence of densities π0,π1,…,πK\pi_0, \pi_1, \dots, \pi_Kπ0​,π1​,…,πK​ recursively by \begin{align} \pi_{k+1}(u) &:= \frac{1}{Z_{k+1}}\pi_k(u)\exp\left(-\frac{1}{K}\Phi(u)\right), &&Z_{k+1} := \int \pi_k(u)\exp\left(-\frac{1}{K}\Phi(u)\right) du, \tag{29} \end{align} for k=0,…,K−1k = 0, \dots, K-1k=0,…,K−1. Then the final density satisfies πK=π\pi_K = \piπK​=π, where π\piπ is defined in (28).

Proof. We first consider the normalizing constant at the final iteration: \begin{align} Z_K &= \int \pi_{K-1}(u)\exp\left(-\frac{1}{K}\Phi(u)\right) du \newline &= \int \pi_{0}(u)\frac{1}{Z_{K-1} \cdots Z_1}\exp\left(-\frac{1}{K}\Phi(u)\right)^K du \newline &= \frac{1}{Z_{K-1} \cdots Z_1} \int \pi_{0}(u)\exp\left(-\Phi(u)\right) du \newline &= \frac{Z}{Z_1 \cdots Z_{K-1}}, \end{align} where the second equality simply iterates the recursion (29). Rearranging, we see that Z=∏k=1KZk.(30) Z = \prod_{k=1}^{K} Z_k. \tag{30} Z=k=1∏K​Zk​.(30)

We similarly iterate the recursion for πK\pi_KπK​: \begin{align} \pi_K(u) &= \frac{1}{Z_K} \pi_{K-1}(u) \exp\left(-\frac{1}{K}\Phi(u)\right) \newline &= \frac{1}{Z_K Z_{K-1} \cdots Z_1} \pi_{0}(u) \exp\left(-\frac{1}{K}\Phi(u)\right)^K \newline &= \frac{1}{Z} \pi_{0}(u) \exp\left(-\Phi(u)\right) \newline &= \pi(u) \qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad\qquad \blacksquare \end{align}

The sequence defined by (29) essentially splits the single Bayesian inverse problem (1) into a sequence of KKK inverse problems. In particular, the update πk↦πk+1\pi_k \mapsto \pi_{k+1}πk​↦πk+1​ implies solving the inverse problem \begin{align} y|u &\sim \tilde{p}(y|u) \tag{31} \newline u &\sim \pi_k(u), \end{align} with the tempered likelihood p~(y∣u)∝exp⁡(−1KΦ(u)).(32) \tilde{p}(y|u) \propto \exp\left(-\frac{1}{K}\Phi(u)\right). \tag{32} p~​(y∣u)∝exp(−K1​Φ(u)).(32) Each update thus encodes the action of conditioning on the data yyy, but under the modified likelihood p~(y∣u)\tilde{p}(y|u)p~​(y∣u) which “spreads out” the information in the data over the KKK time steps. If we were to consider using the true likelihood p(y∣u)p(y|u)p(y∣u) in each time step, this would artificially inflate the information content in yyy, as if we had KKK independent data vectors instead of just one.

Gaussian Special Case

Suppose the likelihood is Gaussian N(y∣G(u),Σ)\mathcal{N}(y|\mathcal{G}(u), \Sigma)N(y∣G(u),Σ), with associated potential Φ(u)=12∥y−G(u)∥Σ2\Phi(u) = \frac{1}{2}\lVert y - \mathcal{G}(u)\rVert^2_{\Sigma}Φ(u)=21​∥y−G(u)∥Σ2​. The tempered likelihood in this case is exp⁡(−1KΦ(u))=exp⁡(−12K∥y−G(u)∥Σ2)∝N(y∣G(u),KΣ).(33) \exp\left(-\frac{1}{K}\Phi(u)\right) = \exp\left(-\frac{1}{2K}\lVert y - \mathcal{G}(u)\rVert^2_{\Sigma}\right) \propto \mathcal{N}(y|\mathcal{G}(u), K\Sigma). \tag{33} exp(−K1​Φ(u))=exp(−2K1​∥y−G(u)∥Σ2​)∝N(y∣G(u),KΣ).(33) The modified likelihood remains Gaussian, and is simply the original likelihood with the variance inflated by a factor of KKK. This matches the intuition from above; the variance is increased to account for the fact that we are conditioning on the same data vector KKK times.

If, in addition to the Gaussian likelihood, the prior π0\pi_0π0​ is Gaussian and the map G\mathcal{G}G is linear then the final posterior π\piπ and each intermediate distribution πk\pi_kπk​ will also be Gaussian. In this case, the recursion (29) defines a sequence of KKK linear Gaussian Bayesian inverse problems.

Introducing Artificial Dynamics

The previous section considered a discrete process on the level of densities; i.e., the dynamics (29) describe the evolution of πk\pi_kπk​. Our goal is now to design an artificial dynamical system that treats uuu as the state variable, such that πk\pi_kπk​ describes the filtering distribution of the state at iteration kkk. In theory, we can then draw samples from π\piπ by applying standard filtering algorithms to this artificial dynamical system.

There are many approaches we could take here, but let us start with the simplest. We know that the update πk↦πk+1\pi_k \mapsto \pi_{k+1}πk​↦πk+1​ should encode the action of conditioning on yyy with respect to the tempered likelihood. Thus, let’s consider the following dynamics and observation model: \begin{align} u_{k+1} &= u_k \tag{34} \newline y_{k+1} &= \mathcal{G}(u_{k+1}) + \epsilon_{k+1}, &&\epsilon_{k+1} \sim \mathcal{N}(0, K\Sigma) \tag{35} \newline u_0 &\sim \pi_0 \tag{36} \end{align} The lines (34) and (36) define our artificial dynamics in uuu, with the former providing the evolution equation and the latter the initial condition. These dynamics are rather uninteresting; the evolution operator is the identity, meaning that the state remains fixed at its initial condition. All of the interesting bits here come into play in the observation model (34). We observe that, by construction, the filtering distribution of this dynamical system at time step kkk is given by πk\pi_kπk​: πk(uk)=p(uk∣y1=y,…,yk=y).(37) \pi_k(u_k) = p(u_k | y_1 = y, \dots, y_k = y). \tag{37} πk​(uk​)=p(uk​∣y1​=y,…,yk​=y).(37) To be clear, we emphasize that the quantities y1,…,yKy_1, \dots, y_Ky1​,…,yK​ in the observation model (35) are random variables, and yk=yy_k = yyk​=y indicates that the condition that the random variable yky_kyk​ is equal to the fixed data realizaton yyy.

Extending the State Space

We now provide an alternative, but equivalent, formulation that gives another useful perspective. Observe that the observation model (34) can be written as yk=G(uk)+ϵk=[0I][ukG(uk)]+ϵk=:Hvk+ϵk,(38) y_k = \mathcal{G}(u_k) + \epsilon_{k} = \begin{bmatrix} 0 & I \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} u_k \\ \mathcal{G}(u_k) \end{bmatrix} + \epsilon_{k} =: Hv_k + \epsilon_k, \tag{38} yk​=G(uk​)+ϵk​=[0​I​][uk​G(uk​)​]+ϵk​=:Hvk​+ϵk​,(38) where we have defined \begin{align} H &:= \begin{bmatrix} 0 & I \end{bmatrix} \in \mathbb{R}^{p \times (d+p)}, &&v_k := \begin{bmatrix} u_k \newline \mathcal{G}(u_k) \end{bmatrix} \in \mathbb{R}^{d+p}. \tag{38} \end{align} We will now adjust the dynamical system (33) to describe the dynamics with respect to the state vector vkv_kvk​: \begin{align} v_{k+1} &= v_k \tag{40} \newline y_{k+1} &= Hv_{k+1} + \epsilon_{k+1}, &&\epsilon_{k+1} \sim \mathcal{N}(0, K\Sigma) \tag{41} \newline u_0 &\sim \pi_0. \tag{42} \end{align} We continue to write the initial condition (42) with respect to uuu but note that the distribution on u0u_0u0​ induces an initial distribution for v0v_0v0​. Why extend the state space in this way? For one, the observation operator in (41) is now linear. Linearity of the observation operator is a common assumption in the data assimilation literature, so satisfying this assumption allows us more flexibility in choosing a filtering algorithm. The main reason I opt to include the state space extension here is that this is the approach taken in Iglesias et al (2012), which is the first paper to systematically propose and analyze the application of the EnKF to inverse problems. In effect, if you have defined the EnKF with respect to a linear observation operator (as is commonly done), then the extended state space formulation allows you to extend the algorithm to the nonlinear case. As we will see, what you ultimately get is identical to the joint Gaussian approximation viewpoint used in deriving (27).

This extended state space formulation still gives rise to the sequence π0,…,πK\pi_0, \dots, \pi_Kπ0​,…,πK​ as before. However, the distribution πk\pi_kπk​ is now a marginal of filtering distribution for vkv_kvk​ (the marginal corresponding to the first ddd entries of vkv_kvk​).

Applying Filtering Algorithms

We have now considered a couple options to formulate the Bayesian inverse problem (1) as a discrete dynamical system, such that the filtering distributions of the artificial system are given by π1,…,πK\pi_1, \dots, \pi_Kπ1​,…,πK​, as defined in (29). The distribution at the final time step satisfies πK=π\pi_K = \piπK​=π. This points to a possible algorithmic approach to posterior inference. If we can propagate an ensemble of particles such that they are distributed according to πk\pi_kπk​ at time step kkk, then the ensemble will represent the posterior at time step KKK. Particle filtering methods might be considered to exactly implement this Monte Carlo scheme. However, in this post we consider approximate methods rooted in Kalman methodology. Specifically, let’s consider applying the EnKF to the model given in (40). We could also consider (34) and get the same result, but I’ll follow Iglesias et al (2012) in using the extended state space formulation to generalize the linear observation operator EnKF to nonlinear operators. A direct application of the EnKF to the system (40) gives the following recursive algorithm.

Posterior Approximation via EnKF Update in Finite Time.

Time k=0:

Generate the initial ensemble {v0(j)}j=1J\{v_0^{(j)}\}_{j=1}^{J}{v0(j)​}j=1J​, where \begin{align} &v^{(j)}_0 := \begin{bmatrix} u^{(j)}_0, \mathcal{G}(u^{(j)}_0) \end{bmatrix}^\top, &&u^{(j)}_0 \overset{iid}{\sim} \pi_0. \tag{43} \end{align} Time k+1:

1. Perform the forecast step: v^k+1(j):=vk(j),j=1,…,J(44) \hat{v}^{(j)}_{k+1} := v^{(j)}_{k}, \qquad j = 1, \dots, J \tag{44} v^k+1(j)​:=vk(j)​,j=1,…,J(44)
2. Compute the sample estimates: \begin{align} \overline{v}_{k+1} &:= \frac{1}{J} \sum_{j=1}^{J} \hat{v}^{(j)}_{k+1} \tag{45} \newline \hat{C}^v_{k+1} &:= \frac{1}{J-1} \sum_{j=1}^{J} (\hat{v}^{(j)}_{k+1} - \overline{v}_{k+1}) (\hat{v}^{(j)}_{k+1} - \overline{v}_{k+1})^\top. \end{align} 3. Perform the analysis step: \begin{align} v^{(j)}_{k+1} &:= \hat{v}^{(j)}_{k+1} + \hat{C}^{v}_{k+1}H^\top[H\hat{C}^{v}_{k+1}H^\top + K\Sigma]^{-1}(y-y^{(j)}), &&y^{(j)} \sim \mathcal{N}(H\hat{v}_{k+1}^{(j)}, K\Sigma). \tag{46} \end{align}

entry.summary: In this post we provide a brief introduction to how ideas related to the Ensemble Kalman Filter (EnKF) can be applied to approximate the posterior distribution of a Bayesian inverse problem. While the EnKF is traditionally applied to time-varying dynamical systems, we show how to introduce artificial dynamics into an otherwise static inverse problem in order to port the EnKF methodology to the inverse problem setting. After defining the inverse problem formulation, we start simply by demonstrating how combining joint Gaussian assumptions with Monte Carlo approximations can provide a means of approximate Bayesian inference. We then generalize this idea by considering a sequence of such joint Gaussian approximations, providing a clear link to the EnKF. These methods are characterized by a finite sequence of updates that map the prior distribution to an (approximate) posterior distribution. We then generalize further by considering a slight adjustment to the EnKF update rules such that the resulting algorithms consist of an infinite sequence of updates. Practical algorithms are defined by truncating after a finite number of steps. Algorithms falling into this class have come to be known as ensemble Kalman inversion (EKI), and have gained much recent interest. We conclude by briefly highlighting connections to measure transport.

entry.title: Pseudo-Marginal MCMC
entry.content:
Pseudo-marginal Markov chain Monte Carlo (MCMC) is a variant of the Metropolis-Hastings algorithm that works without the ability to evaluate the unnormalized target density, so long as an unbiased sample of this density can be obtained for any input. In this post, we motivate the algorithm by considering a problem of Bayesian inference where the likelihood function is intractable. We then take a step back to understand why the algorithm works, and discuss the method from a more generic and rigorous viewpoint.

Pseudo-Marginal MCMC for Bayesian Inference

We start by considering a standard problem of Bayesian inference for a parameter of interest u∈Uu \in \mathcal{U}u∈U. Given a prior density π0(u)\pi_0(u)π0​(u) and likelihood function L(u)L(u)L(u), the unnormalized posterior density is then obtained as the product of these two quantities: π(u):=π0(u)L(u).(1) \pi(u) := \pi_0(u) L(u). \tag{1} π(u):=π0​(u)L(u).(1) With the ability to evaluate this unnormalized density, MCMC algorithms can be applied to obtain samples from the posterior distribution. However, suppose we face a situation where L(u)L(u)L(u) is intractable in the sense that it does not admit an analytic expression that can be computed for any uuu. Suppose, though, that we can draw an unbiased sample of the quantity L(u)L(u)L(u) for any input uuu; that is, \begin{align} &\ell \sim P(u, \cdot), &&\mathbb{E}[\ell] = L(u), \tag{2} \end{align} where P(u,⋅)P(u,\cdot)P(u,⋅) is a probability measure on the sample space [0,∞)[0, \infty)[0,∞) for each u∈Uu \in \mathcal{U}u∈U (formally, we can think of PPP as a Markov kernel). It turns out that this is sufficient to define an MCMC algorithm with target distribution equal uuu’s posterior. The algorithm that accomplishes this is referred as pseudo-marginal MCMC. A single step of this algorithm is detailed below.

Pseudo-Marginal MCMC. Let uuu be the current state of the algorithm, with ℓ∼P(u,⋅)\ell \sim P(u,\cdot)ℓ∼P(u,⋅) the associated unbiased likelihood sample. Let QQQ denote the proposal kernel. The next state is then determined as follows.
1. Propose a new state: u~∼Q(u,⋅)(3) \tilde{u} \sim Q(u, \cdot) \tag{3} u~∼Q(u,⋅)(3) 2. Draw an unbiased likelihood sample at the proposed state: ℓ~∼P(u~,⋅)(4) \tilde{\ell} \sim P(\tilde{u}, \cdot) \tag{4} ℓ~∼P(u~,⋅)(4) 3. With probability α(u,ℓ;u~,ℓ~):=min⁡(1,π0(u~)ℓ~q(u~,u)π0(u)ℓq(u,u~)),(5) \alpha(u,\ell; \tilde{u},\tilde{\ell}) := \min\left(1, \frac{\pi_0(\tilde{u})\tilde{\ell}q(\tilde{u},u)}{\pi_0(u)\ell q(u,\tilde{u})} \right), \tag{5} α(u,ℓ;u~,ℓ~):=min(1,π0​(u)ℓq(u,u~)π0​(u~)ℓ~q(u~,u)​),(5) set the new state to u~\tilde{u}u~. Else set it to the current state uuu.

Notice that the acceptance probability (5) is the typical Metropolis-Hastings acceptance probability but with the unbiased likelihood samples ℓ\ellℓ and ℓ~\tilde{\ell}ℓ~ inserted in place of L(u)L(u)L(u) and L(u~)L(\tilde{u})L(u~), respectively. The claim is that this algorithm defines a Markov chain with invariant distribution π\piπ. To see why this is true, the trick is to view the above algorithm as a Metropolis-Hastings scheme operating on the extended state vector (u,ℓ)(u, \ell)(u,ℓ). In showing this, I will assume P(u,⋅)P(u,\cdot)P(u,⋅) and Q(u,⋅)Q(u,\cdot)Q(u,⋅) admit densities p(u,⋅)p(u,\cdot)p(u,⋅) and q(u,⋅)q(u,\cdot)q(u,⋅) with respect to the same base measure for which π\piπ is a density (typically, the Lebesgue or counting measure.) Now, to view the above algorithm with respect to the extended state space, start by noticing that (3) and (4) can be interpreted as a joint proposal (u~,ℓ~)∼Q‾(u,ℓ;⋅,⋅),(6) (\tilde{u},\tilde{\ell}) \sim \overline{Q}(u,\ell; \cdot, \cdot), \tag{6} (u~,ℓ~)∼Q​(u,ℓ;⋅,⋅),(6) with Q‾\overline{Q}Q​ a Markov kernel on the product space U×[0,∞)\mathcal{U} \times [0,\infty)U×[0,∞) with density q‾(u,ℓ;u~,ℓ~):=q(u,u~)p(u~,ℓ~).(7) \overline{q}(u,\ell; \tilde{u},\tilde{\ell}) := q(u,\tilde{u})p(\tilde{u},\tilde{\ell}). \tag{7} q​(u,ℓ;u~,ℓ~):=q(u,u~)p(u~,ℓ~).(7) Notice that Q‾(u,ℓ;⋅,⋅)\overline{Q}(u,\ell; \cdot, \cdot)Q​(u,ℓ;⋅,⋅) is independent of ℓ\ellℓ. It now remains to write the acceptance probability (5) in a form that can be interpreted with respect to the extended state space. To this end, consider \begin{align} \frac{\pi_0(\tilde{u})\tilde{\ell}q(\tilde{u},u)}{\pi_0(u)\ell q(u,\tilde{u})} &= \frac{\pi_0(\tilde{u})\tilde{\ell}}{\pi_0(u)\ell} \cdot \frac{q(\tilde{u},u)p(u,\ell)}{q(u,\tilde{u})p(\tilde{u},\tilde{\ell})} \cdot \frac{p(\tilde{u},\tilde{\ell})}{p(u,\ell)} \newline &= \frac{\pi_0(\tilde{u})\tilde{\ell}p(\tilde{u},\tilde{\ell})}{\pi_0(u)\ell p(\tilde{u},\tilde{\ell})} \cdot \frac{\overline{q}(\tilde{u},\tilde{\ell};u,\ell)}{\overline{q}(u,\ell;\tilde{u},\tilde{\ell})}. \tag{8} \end{align} The second term is the proposal density ratio with respect to extended proposal q‾\overline{q}q​. Thus, the function appearing in the numerator and denominator of the first term must be the (unnormalized) density targeted by this Metropolis-Hastings scheme. In other words, the invariant distribution implied by the above algorithm has unnormalized density π‾(u,ℓ):=π0(u)p(u,ℓ)ℓ.(9) \overline{\pi}(u,\ell) := \pi_0(u)p(u,\ell)\ell. \tag{9} π(u,ℓ):=π0​(u)p(u,ℓ)ℓ.(9) Notice that π0(u)ℓ\pi_0(u)\ellπ0​(u)ℓ is the unnormalized density (1) with the sample ℓ\ellℓ inserted in place of L(u)L(u)L(u). This is multiplied by the weight p(u,ℓ)p(u,\ell)p(u,ℓ), which encodes the probability of sampling ℓ\ellℓ at the input uuu. Our proof of the algorithm’s correctness is concluded by noting that π‾\overline{\pi}π admits π\piπ as a marginal distribution; indeed, \begin{align} \int \overline{\pi}(u,\ell)d\ell &= \int \pi_0(u)p(u,\ell)\ell d\ell = \pi_0(u) \int \ell \cdot p(u,\ell) d\ell = \pi_0(u) \mathbb{E}[\ell|u] = \pi_0(u) L(u), \tag{10} \end{align} following from the unbiasedness of the likelihood sample. This means that, in theory, we can run the above algorithm to obtain joint samples (u,ℓ)∼π‾(u,\ell) \sim \overline{\pi}(u,ℓ)∼π, and then simply extract the uuu portion of these pairs to obtain the desired draws u∼πu \sim \piu∼π. One last thing to note is that we don’t actually need to be able to evaluate the density p(u,ℓ)p(u,\ell)p(u,ℓ) appearing in (8); we see in the acceptance probability (5) that we need only be able to sample from P(u,⋅)P(u,\cdot)P(u,⋅). As usual, we need to be able to evaluate the density q(u,u~)q(u,\tilde{u})q(u,u~).

A More Generic and Formal Perspective

The above idea of course extends beyond the Bayesian example. In this section, we discuss the pseudo-marginal algorithm from a more generic perspective, and fill in some of the measure-theoretic details. Let’s assume Π\PiΠ is some generic target distribution on a measurable space (U,B(U))(\mathcal{U}, \mathcal{B}(\mathcal{U}))(U,B(U)). We write B(U)\mathcal{B}(\mathcal{U})B(U) to denote the Borel σ\sigmaσ-algebra; that is, the σ\sigmaσ-algebra generated by the open sets of U\mathcal{U}U. We assume Π\PiΠ admits a density (i.e., Radon-Nikodym derivative) π\piπ with respect to some reference measure ν\nuν. The density π\piπ need not be normalized. All densities considered throughout this section will be with respect to the same reference measure ν\nuν. As before, we consider π(u)\pi(u)π(u) intractable, but assume we can draw samples from an unbiased estimator. We could define P(u,⋅)P(u,\cdot)P(u,⋅) as before such that samples drawn from P(u,⋅)P(u,\cdot)P(u,⋅) are unbiased with respect to π(u)\pi(u)π(u). However, note that this is equivalent to considering samples w∼P(u,⋅)w \sim P(u,\cdot)w∼P(u,⋅) with expectation 111, such that w⋅π(u)w \cdot \pi(u)w⋅π(u) is unbiased for π(u)\pi(u)π(u). This seems to be a roundabout way to go around this, but for the purposes of analysis it turns out to be convenient. This is the definition used in some of the “noisy MCMC” literature (see, e.g., Medina-Aguayo et al, 2018). Thus, let’s go with this definition and define the Markov kernel P:U→[0,1]P: \mathcal{U} \to [0,1]P:U→[0,1] such that (1) P(u,⋅)P(u,\cdot)P(u,⋅) is a probability measure on (W,B(W))(\mathcal{W},\mathcal{B}(\mathcal{W}))(W,B(W)) for each u∈Uu \in \mathcal{U}u∈U, where W⊆[0,∞)\mathcal{W} \subseteq [0,\infty)W⊆[0,∞); and (2) PPP produces weights with unit expectation: \begin{align} &w \sim P(u,\cdot), &&\mathbb{E}_{P_u}[w] = 1. \tag{11} \end{align} We use PuP_uPu​ as shorthand for P(u,⋅)P(u,\cdot)P(u,⋅) in the subscript. We again emphasize that the sample www from (11) implies that wπ(u)w\pi(u)wπ(u) is an unbiased estimate of π(u)\pi(u)π(u). The pseudo-marginal algorithm proceeds exactly as before. We state it again below to emphasize the new notation.

1. Propose a new state: u~∼Q(u,⋅)(12) \tilde{u} \sim Q(u, \cdot) \tag{12} u~∼Q(u,⋅)(12) 2. Draw an unbiased weight sample at the proposed state: w~∼P(u~,⋅)(13) \tilde{w} \sim P(\tilde{u}, \cdot) \tag{13} w~∼P(u~,⋅)(13) 3.
